Rule.desc: Do not pass negative values to functions expecting non-negative arguments
Always catch exceptions
Avoid use before initialization
Avoid null pointer dereferencing
Avoid buffer overflow due to defining incorrect format limits
Avoid overflow due to reading a not zero terminated string
Avoid overflow when reading from a buffer
Avoid overflow when writing to a buffer
Avoid division by zero
Avoid accessing arrays out of bounds
Avoid conditions that always evaluate to the same value
Do not check for null after dereferencing
Suspicious setting of stream flags
Restore stream format
Properly deallocate dynamically allocated resources
Do not use resources that have been freed
Do not free resources using invalid pointers
Ensure resources are freed
Avoid double locking
Avoid race conditions when using fork and file descriptors
Do not abandon unreleased locks
Do not acquire locks in different order
Avoid race conditions while checking for the existence of a symbolic link
Do not use blocking functions while holding a lock
Avoid function duplication
Local variables should not use the same names as member variables
Pointer should not be compared with NULL using relational operators <, >, >=, <=
Do not use string literals as operands of equality or relational operators
Avoid infinite loops
Constructors allowing for conversion should be made explicit
Throw by value, catch by reference
Do not throw from within destructor
All member variables should be initialized in constructor
McCabe Cyclomatic Complexity
Nested Blocks Depth
Floating-point expressions shall not be tested for equality or inequality
All exit paths from a function with non-void return type shall have an explicit return statement with an expression
The address of an object with automatic storage shall not be returned from a function
Do not invoke malloc/realloc for objects having constructors
Declare a copy assignment operator for classes with dynamically allocated memory
Declare a copy constructor for classes with dynamically allocated memory
Never provide brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating non-arrays
Always provide empty brackets ([]) for delete when deallocating arrays
Do not use 'delete' on pointers to a void type
Class cannot inherit other class more than once unless it is virtual inheritance
Avoid calling virtual functions from constructors
If a class has virtual functions it shall have a virtual destructor
Pass objects by reference instead of by value
Do not call delete on non-pointers
Properly terminate character strings
Do not cast from or to incomplete class at the point of casting
Do not delete objects with incomplete class at the point of deletion
Boolean condition always evaluates to the same value due to enumeration with only zero or only non-zero constants
Suspicious argument to malloc
Pointer arithmetic performed on freshly allocated memory
